dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 420 point drop in the Dow—that's a pretty sharp decline, but I't's not like we haven't seen volatility before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A four hundred twenty point drop in the Dow-that's a pretty sharp decline, but I't's not like we haven't seen volatility before.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones industrial average soared 420 points, or 1.4%, Wednesday, while the S&P 500, which broke a five-day losing streak on Tuesday, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq climbed 1.1% and 1%, respectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but this time it's tied directly to Jerome Powell's comments on inflation, which really spooked the markets. He basically doubled down on restrictive monetary policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but this time it's tied directly to Jerome Powell's comments on inflation, which really spooked the markets. He basically doubled down on restrictive monetary policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yields on the ten-year Treasurywhich moves inversely to stocksrose 50 basis points Wednesday morning to 1.4%, tacking on to their highest level since last February following congressional testimony from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, who insisted Tuesday that monetary policy would remain accommodative despite inflationary concerns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But energy stocks have been tanking all year, right? The S&P Energy Index is down, what, 27%? That's not just a one-day thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But energy stocks have been tanking all year, right? The S&P Energy Index is down, what, twenty seven percent? That's not just a one-day thing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Energy firms continued to head up market gains, with Occidental Petroleum, EOG Resources and Cabot Oil & Gas up 8%, 7% and 6%, respectively; the S&P 500 Energy Index has soared 27% this yearmore than double the return of any other sector over the same period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and that's part of why Powell's remarks hit so hard—investors were already nervous, especially with names like Occidental Petroleum and Cabot Oil & Gas dropping big.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and that's part of why Powell's remarks hit so hard-investors were already nervous, especially with names like Occidental Petroleum and Cabot Oil and Gas dropping big.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Energy firms continued to head up market gains, with Occidental Petroleum, EOG Resources and Cabot Oil & Gas up 8%, 7% and 6%, respectively; the S&P 500 Energy Index has soared 27% this yearmore than double the return of any other sector over the same period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, tech did okay though—Apple, Amazon, they were up almost 1%. Doesn't that suggest it's not all doom and gloom?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, tech did okay though-Apple, Amazon, they were up almost one percent. Doesn't that suggest it's not all doom and gloom?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Technology stocks, on the other hand, continued to slip: Apple, Amazon and Facebook all fell close to 1% Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure, but then you've got Fisker Inc., um, plunging 40% after ending their Foxconn deal. It's not a uniform sell-off, but the overall sentiment is shaky.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure, but then you've got Fisker Inc., um, plunging forty percent after ending their Foxconn deal. It's not a uniform sell-off, but the overall sentiment is shaky.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elsewhere in the market, Tesla rival Fisker Inc. soared nearly 40%, surpassing a record high from November, after announcing a collaboration with Taiwanese manufacturer Foxconn on a new electric vehicle project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And what about this flattening yield curve? Craig Erlam from Oanda called it a "smooth period," which feels ironic given the numbers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what about this flattening yield curve? Craig Erlam from Oanda called it a smooth period, which feels ironic given the numbers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Were going through a very choppy period in the markets, with investors uncertain how to read the movements were seeing in bond markets, Oanda Senior Market Analyst Craig Erlam said Wednesday morning. The curve is steepening, and investors are fretting a little about the prospect of higher inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think he means smooth in a… concerning way? Like, investors aren't panicking yet, but there's this underlying anxiety about deflation and how policymakers will react.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think he means smooth in a... concerning way? Like, investors aren't panicking yet, but there's this underlying anxiety about deflation and how policymakers will react.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The curve is steepening, and investors are fretting a little about the prospect of higher inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then there's bitcoin—MicroStrategy sold a billion dollars worth. Seems like even crypto isn't immune to this uncertainty.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then there's bitcoin-MicroStrategy sold a billion dollars worth. Seems like even crypto isn't immune to this uncertainty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Publicly traded MicroStrategy, one of the largest corporate bitcoin investors, said Wednesday morning it spent approximately $1 billion to acquire 19,452 more bitcoin tokens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but Square actually soared after divesting some of their bitcoin stake. It's such a mixed bag, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but Square actually soared after divesting some of their bitcoin stake. It's such a mixed bag, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of payments fintech Square, meanwhile, sank about 7% after the firm disclosed in a better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings report that it has doubled down on a $50 million bitcoin investment from October, purchasing $170 million more of the worlds largest cryptocurrency since.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So where does that leave us? Powell says we might hit a deflation target in under three months—is that good or bad for the recovery?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So where does that leave us? Powell says we might hit a deflation target in under three months-is that good or bad for the recovery?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Originally down in early morning trading, stocks surged after Fed Chair Powell downplayed inflation concerns before the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday, saying that it may take the U.S. more than three years to reach a key inflation target.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think it depends on whether it's temporary. If lawmakers get aggressive, we could see more stability, or maybe just more volatility. It's hard to call.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think it depends on whether it's temporary. If lawmakers get aggressive, we could see more stability, or maybe just more volatility. It's hard to call.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True. For now, though, it looks like the market's taking every signal and amplifying it—for better or worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. For now, though, it looks like the market's taking every signal and amplifying it-for better or worse.

artist_script:
HostA: A 420 point drop in the Dow—that’s a pretty sharp decline, but I’t’s not like we haven’t seen volatility before.
HostB: Yeah, but this time it’s tied directly to Jerome Powell’s comments on inflation, which really spooked the markets. He basically doubled down on restrictive monetary policy.
HostA: But energy stocks have been tanking all year, right? The S&P Energy Index is down, what, 27%? That’s not just a one-day thing.
HostB: Exactly, and that’s part of why Powell’s remarks hit so hard—investors were already nervous, especially with names like Occidental Petroleum and Cabot Oil & Gas dropping big.
HostA: Still, tech did okay though—Apple, Amazon, they were up almost 1%. Doesn’t that suggest it’s not all doom and gloom?
HostB: For sure, but then you’ve got Fisker Inc., um, plunging 40% after ending their Foxconn deal. It’s not a uniform sell-off, but the overall sentiment is shaky.
HostA: And what about this flattening yield curve? Craig Erlam from Oanda called it a "smooth period," which feels ironic given the numbers.
HostB: I think he means smooth in a… concerning way? Like, investors aren’t panicking yet, but there’s this underlying anxiety about deflation and how policymakers will react.
HostA: Right, and then there’s bitcoin—MicroStrategy sold a billion dollars worth. Seems like even crypto isn’t immune to this uncertainty.
HostB: Yeah, but Square actually soared after divesting some of their bitcoin stake. It’s such a mixed bag, honestly.
HostA: So where does that leave us? Powell says we might hit a deflation target in under three months—is that good or bad for the recovery?
HostB: I think it depends on whether it’s temporary. If lawmakers get aggressive, we could see more stability, or maybe just more volatility. It’s hard to call.
HostA: True. For now, though, it looks like the market’s taking every signal and amplifying it—for better or worse.
